title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient Care amendment to provide hospital care and nursing home care for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. The amendment expands outpatient care for veterans, including those who served in the Southwest Asia theater of operations during the Persian Gulf War, before December 31, 1994. The amendment expands outpatient care for veterans, including those who served in the Southwest Asia theater of operations during the Persian Gulf War, by providing medical services for disabilities possibly caused by exposure to toxic substances or environmental hazards. The effective date of the amendments is August 2, 1990, and veterans can request reimbursement for payments made to the United States under certain circumstances. The Act extends healthcare eligibility for veterans exposed to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. Reimbursement is provided for payments made for hospital care or outpatient services. Additionally, amendments expand outpatient care for veterans with disabilities possibly caused by exposure to toxic substances. The Act extends eligibility for sexual trauma counseling for women veterans and adjusts various deadlines for different provisions related to veterans' healthcare and benefits. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of the amendment is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. The definition of "health-care resource" is expanded to include various services and support. Sharing of health-care resources with State homes is authorized under the amendment. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources and general health-care resources. This aims to improve care for veterans by facilitating the mutual use of resources between Department health-care facilities and other institutions. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, ensuring resources are used effectively for veterans' care.
